item.title: sin⁻¹(x) + cos⁻¹(x) = π/2
item.description:
Proof:

Let’s consider the functions \( \sin^{-1}(x) \) (arcsine) and \( \cos^{-1}(x) \) (arccosine). We aim to prove that:

\[ \sin^{-1}(x) + \cos^{-1}(x) = \frac{\pi}{2} \]

Step 1: Define Variables

\[ \theta = \sin^{-1}(x) \]\[ \sin(\theta) = x \]\[ -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} \]

Step 2: Use the Complementary Angle Identity

\[ \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \theta\right) = \sin(\theta) \]\[ \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \theta\right) = x \]

Step 3: Apply the Arccos Function

\[ \cos^{-1}(x) = \frac{\pi}{2} - \theta \]\[ \cos^{-1}(x) = \frac{\pi}{2} - \sin^{-1}(x) \]
